case_name: Appellant v. State Bank of India

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 707 of 1962 was an appeal by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 707 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the order dated

facts.text: Appeal was from the order dated December 11, 1961 of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi in C.A. No. 605 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 11, 1961, of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi in C.A. No. 605 of 1961.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on April 22, 1963 by DAS GUPTA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. April 22. The judgment of the Court was delivered by DAS GUPTA J.-

facts.text: Appellant was appointed as a clerk in the State Bank of India on December 14, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was appointed as a clerk in the State Bank of India, the respondent before us, on December 14, 1953.

facts.text: At appointment, appellant's salary was Rs. 95/- per month with dearness allowance of Rs. 50/-

anchor.surface_text: At the time of appointment his salary was Rs. 95/- per month with a dearness allowance of Rs. 50/-

facts.text: Sastry Award was given statutory force by the Industrial Disputes (Banking Companies) Decisions Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Sastry Award in the disputes between certain banking companies and their workmen as modified by the labour Appellate Tribunal was given statutory force by the Industrial Disputes  Banking Companies  Decisions Act, 1955.

facts.text: Sastry Award is applicable to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: In applying to the appellant this award which is admittedly applicable to him

facts.text: Bank proceeded to give appellant annual increments on April 1 each year under Sastry Award.

anchor.surface_text: In applying to the appellant this award which is admittedly applicable to him the bank proceeded on the basis that under it the appellant was entitled to get his annual increment in each year on April 1.

facts.text: Appellant claims entitlement to annual increments in December each year under the award.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant, however, he is entitled under the award to have his annual increment in December each year.

facts.text: Appellant made application under s. 33C(2) of Industrial Disputes Act on December 14, 1960 before Labour Court, Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: On December 14, 1960, the appellant made an application under s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act before the Labour Court, Delhi,

facts.text: Application sought computation and payment of benefit under award deprived by bank's error.

anchor.surface_text: praying that the benefit under the award of which he is being deprived by the bank by the alleged error in its implementation should be companyputed and directed to be paid to him.

facts.text: Schedule to application claimed additional Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance based on increments on December 14.

anchor.surface_text: A schedule was annexed to the application purporting to show that on the basis that the annual increment has to be allowed on December 14, of each year and number on April, 1, the appellant was entitled to an additional sum of Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance.

facts.text: Bank raised preliminary objection that entitlement question cannot be decided under s.33C(2).

anchor.surface_text: In resisting this application the Bank raised a preliminary objection that the question whether or number the appellant was entitled to the benefits as alleged by him companyld number be raised or decided in an application under s. 33  c   2 .

facts.text: Bank pleaded on merits that it acted per Sastry Award by allowing increments on April 1 each year.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits the bank pleaded that it had acted in accordance with the terms of the Sastry Award in allowing increments on the 1st April of each year.

facts.text: Labour Court rejected preliminary objection but held annual increments due after April 1, 1954 and on April 1 succeeding years; rejected application.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court rejected the preliminary objection but held on the merits that the annual increment of the appellant fell due from after April 1, 1954, and on April 1, in succeeding years. Accordingly, the Court rejected the application.

facts.text: Appeal filed by special leave against Labour Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order of rejection this appeal has been filed by special leave of this companyrt.

facts.text: Appellant contends Labour Court erred in holding increments fall due on April 1 from 1954 for workmen appointed after Jan 31, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Before us the appellant companytends that the Labour Court has erred in thinking that tinder the award annual increments to workmen appointed after January 31, 1950 and before the new scales were brought into force, fell due on April 1, of each year, starting from April 1, 1954.

facts.text: Respondent contended Labour Court wrongly rejected preliminary objection.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in addition to supporting the decision of the Labour Court on merits further companytended that the Court had wrongly rejected the preliminary objection raised by the bank.

facts.text: Revised scales of pay brought into operation under para 627 with effect from April 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under para 627 with effect from April 1, 1953.

facts.text: Sastry Award signed by Tribunal members between March 5 and March 20, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The award, it may be mentioned, was signed by the members of the Tribunal between March 5, and March 20, 1953.

facts.text: Appellant appointed after date new scales came into force, so gets increments on December 14 each year under new scale.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the present appellant appointed on December 14, 1953 would get the benefit of the new scales of pay from the very date of his appointment In companysequence., he would get the increments under the new scale on December 14 of each year

facts.text: Appellant entitled to Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance under Sastry Award, not paid by bank.

anchor.surface_text: He is therefore entitled to Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance as the benefit to which he is entitled- under the Sastry Award but which has number been paid.

facts.text: Court allows appeal, sets aside Labour Court order, computes sum at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court was, therefore, wrong in rejecting the appellants petition. We allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court, Delhi, and companypute the sum to which he is entitled under the Award at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance.

facts.text: Other four petitions before Labour Court: two appointed Feb 24, 1950, one March 15, 1951, one June 1, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that in other four petitions, two persons were appointed on February 24, 1950, one on March 15, 1951 and one on June 1, 1953, while the appellant, as already stated, was appointed on December 14, 1953.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated December 11, 1961, of the Central Government Labour Court, Delhi in C.A. No. 605 of 1961.
Against this order of rejection this appeal has been filed by special leave of this court.

The Sastry Award in the disputes between certain banking companies and their workmen as modified by the labour Appellate Tribunal was given statutory force by the Industrial Disputes  Banking Companies  Decisions Act, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act has been elaborately considered by us in the Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan  1 , and we have decided there that the Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether or number the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.

issues.text: Whether the Labour Court has jurisdiction under Section 33C(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act to decide on an examination of an award whether the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act has been elaborately considered by us in the Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan  1 , and we have decided there that the Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether or number the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.

issues.text: Whether under the Sastry Award the appellant appointed on December 14, 1953 is entitled to annual increments on December 14 each year rather than on April 1, and whether para 292 applies to such appointees

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to notice that para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay.

issues.text: Whether para 292 of the Sastry Award which provides that adjusted pay shall have effect from April 1, 1954 applies to persons appointed after January 31, 1950 but before April 1, 1954 or only to existing staff

anchor.surface_text: para. 292 12  which after modification by the Labour Appellate Tribunal says The adjusted pay shall have effect from April 1, 1954.

arguments.claim: The Labour Court has erred in thinking that under the award annual increments to workmen appointed after January 31, 1950 and before the new scales were brought into force, fell due on April 1, of each year, starting from April 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Before us the appellant contends that the Labour Court has erred in thinking that tinder the award annual increments to workmen appointed after January 31, 1950 and before the new scales were brought into force, fell due on April 1, of each year, starting from April 1, 1954.

arguments.court_reasoning: Agreed; para 292 limited to existing staff before revised scales.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in addition to supporting the decision of the Labour Court on merits further contended that the Court had wrongly rejected the preliminary objection raised by the bank.

arguments.court_reasoning: Labour Court correctly had jurisdiction as per Central Bank precedent.

arguments.claim: The Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act has been elaborately considered by us in the Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan  1 , and we have decided there that the Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether or number the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.

arguments.claim: Under the Sastry Award his pay had to be fixed in accordance with the directions in cl. 7 of para 292 but that the bank had wrongly fixed his pay on the same basis as the employees who entered service before January 31, 1950; annual increment would have fallen due on December 14 each year.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case in the written statement was that under the Sastry Award his pay had to be fixed in accordance with the directions in cl. 7 of para 292 but that the bank had wrongly fixed his pay on the same basis as the employees who entered service of the respondent before January 31, 1950.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under par

arguments.court_reasoning: Para 292 not applicable at all to appellant as new appointee; but increments on Dec 14 correct under new scales.

arguments.claim: As the adjusted salary would have effect under para. 292 from April 1,1954 the increments were rightly given on April 1, of each year, after April 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The bank contended however that as the adjusted salary would have effect under para. 292  1  1964 Vol, 3 S. C. R. 140. from April l,1954 the increments were rightly given on April 1, of each year, after April 1, 1954.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under par

arguments.court_reasoning: Para 292 only for existing staff; appellant not covered.

arguments.claim: Para 292(12) 'The adjusted pay shall have effect from April 1, 1954' applies to all persons appointed after January 31, 1950 but before April 1, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: In all the cases the Labour Court accepted the banks contention based on para. 292 12  which after modification by the Labour Appellate Tribunal says The adjusted pay shall have effect from April 1, 1954. The Court was of opinion that this rule should apply to all persons appointed after January 31, 1950 but before April 1, 1954.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under par

arguments.court_reasoning: Para 292 specifically for fitting existing staff into revised scales; not for new joinees after scales operative.

arguments.claim: Para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay; revised scales operative from April 1, 1953 per para 627; appellant appointed Dec 14, 1953 after, so straight into new scales with increments on Dec 14 each year.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to notice that para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under para 627 with effect from April 1, 1953.

holdings.text: The Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him. The preliminary objection must therefore be held to have been rightly rejected by the Court.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act has been elaborately considered by us in the Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan  1 , and we have decided there that the Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether or number the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows binding precedent from Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan affirming Labour Court's jurisdiction under s.33C(2) to interpret awards and determine workman entitlements.

holdings.text: Para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay; persons who joined the service of the bank after the date when the new scales came into force would not be governed by para. 292 for the simple reason that they were not existing staff of the bank.

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to notice that para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under para 627 with effect from April 1, 1953.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of para. 292 in context with para. 627 (revised scales effective April 1, 1953) and award date limits it to pre-existing staff; new joinees enter directly into revised scales.

holdings.text: The present appellant appointed on December 14, 1953 would get the benefit of the new scales of pay from the very date of his appointment. In consequence, he would get the increments under the new scale on December 14 of each year and would thus be entitled to Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance as the benefit to which he is entitled under the Sastry Award but which has not been paid.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the present appellant appointed on December 14, 1953 would get the benefit of the new scales of pay from the very date of his appointment In consequence., he would get the increments under the new scale on December 14 of each year

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant appointed after revised scales operative date (April 1, 1953) not covered by para. 292; directly on new scales with increments from appointment anniversary (December 14).

holdings.text: The Labour Court was, therefore, wrong in rejecting the appellants petition. We allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court, Delhi, and compute the sum to which he is entitled under the Award at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance.

anchor.surface_text: The Labour Court was, therefore, wrong in rejecting the appellants petition. We allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court, Delhi, and compute the sum to which he is entitled under the Award at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allowance.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower court erroneously applied para. 292 to appellant; correct interpretation entitles to claimed benefits.

anchor.surface_text: The scope of s. 33  c   2  of the Industrial Disputes Act has been elaborately considered by us in the Central Bank of India Ltd. v. P.S. Rajagopalan  1 , and we have decided there that the Labour Court has got jurisdiction to decide on an examination of an award or settlement whether or number the workman is entitled to the benefits claimed by him.
We allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court, Delhi, and compute the sum to which he is entitled under the Award at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allow

anchor.surface_text: It is necessary to notice that para. 292 of the award dealt with the question of fitting the existing staff into the revised scales of pay. The revised scales of pay were brought into operation under para 627 with effect from April 1, 1953.
We allow the appeal, set aside the order of the Labour Court, Delhi, and compute the sum to which he is entitled under the Award at Rs. 146/- plus dearness allow
